required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Evaluation of a Silicone Hydrogel Lens

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the performance of an investigational contact lens among contact lens wearers.

primary_outcome.description: Overall preference when comparing study lenses to "habitual" lenses, as interpreted by the participant and reported on a questionnaire as a single, retrospective evaluation of four weeks' wear time. Overall preference was measured on a 5-point Likert scale as follows: Strongly Prefer Study Lenses; Somewhat Prefer Study Lenses; No Preference; Somewhat Prefer "Habitual" Lenses; Strongly Prefer "Habitual" Lenses.

intervention.description: Investigational silicone hydrogel, single-vision, soft contact lens worn for four weeks at least as often as and on the same basis as participant's habitual lenses, as prescribed by participant's eye care practitioner -- ie., on a daily wear, flex wear, or extended wear basis.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Currently wearing lotrafilcon A lenses in both eyes for a minimum of 5 days per week, 8 hours per day, for 3 months.
- Removes contact lenses daily or sleeps overnight in contact lenses (up to 30 consecutive nights) as prescribed by regular eye care practitioner.
- Able to achieve distance visual acuity of at least 20/40 in each eye with study lenses.
- Other protocol inclusion/exclusion criteria may apply.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Eye injury or surgery within 12 months prior to enrollment.
- Currently enrolled in any clinical trial.
- History of corneal refractive surgery.
- Other protocol inclusion/exclusion criteria may apply.

group.title: All Participants
group.description: In this single group study, all participants wore an investigational lotrafilcon A silicone hydrogel, single-vision, soft contact lens in both eyes for a period of four weeks. Participants wore the study lenses at least as often as they wore their habitual lenses, and as prescribed by their eye care practitioners -- ie., on a daily wear, flex wear, or extended wear basis.

Participants wore the study lenses at least as often as they wore their habitual lenses, and as prescribed by their eye care practitioners -- ie., on a daily wear, flex wear, or extended wear basis.

outcome.title: Overall Preference
outcome.description: Overall preference when comparing study lenses to "habitual" lenses, as interpreted by the participant and reported on a questionnaire as a single, retrospective evaluation of four weeks' wear time. Overall preference was measured on a 5-point Likert scale as follows: Strongly Prefer Study Lenses; Somewhat Prefer Study Lenses; No Preference; Somewhat Prefer "Habitual" Lenses; Strongly Prefer "Habitual" Lenses.
outcome.population: Analysis conducted per protocol, with exclusions due to reasons such as: major protocol deviations as determined by masked review; discontinuations; and/or missing responses.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data were collected for the duration of the trial: 49 days

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: For a period of 10 years, the clinical investigator must hold all trial-related information and documents confidential and must agree to obtain sponsor's written consent before discussing, presenting, publicizing, or otherwise disclosing any preclinical and/or clinical data or impressions from this trial.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Priya Janakiraman, OD, FAAO / Head, Global Clinical Affairs
